The maximum amount of shared (deduplicated, cloned) data on
a Data ONTAP FlexVol (i.e. a Cinder pool) is 640TB.  The only thing

it. The symptom is that operations such as cloning Cinder volumes

level of consumption to the scheduler for optional incorporation
into the filter & goodness functions, so that pools nearing the shared

subject: Remove xrange for run both Python 2 and Python 3
commit_message:
Remove xrange for run both Python 2 and Python 3

In python 3, range() does what xrange() used to do and xrange() does not
exist. If you want to write code that will run on both Python 2 and
Python 3, you can't use xrange().

range() can actually be faster in some cases - eg. if iterating over the
same sequence multiple times. xrange() has to reconstruct the integer
object every time, but range() will have real integer objects.
(It will always perform worse in terms of memory however)

xrange() isn't usable in all cases where a real list is needed.
For instance, it doesn't support slices, or any list methods.

subject: Fix signal handling for daemons with InternalClient
commit_message:
Fix signal handling for daemons with InternalClient

The intentional use of "bare except" handling in catch_errors and some
daemons to prevent propagation on unexpected errors that do not
inherit from Exception (like eventlet.Timeout) or even BaseException
(like old-style classes) has the side effect of spuriously "handling"
*expected* errors like when a signal handler raises SystemExit.

The signal handler installed in our Daemon is intended to ensure first
that the entire process group and any forked processes (like rsync's)
receive the SIGTERM signal and also that the process itself
terminates.

The use of sys.exit was not a concious grandiose plans for graceful
shutdown (like the running[0] = False trick that wsgi server parent
process do) - the desired behavior for SIGTERM is to stop - hard.

This change ensures the original goals and intentions of our signal
handler are fulfilled without the undesirable side effect that can
cause our daemons to confusingly log an expected message to stop as an
unexpected error, and start ignoring additional SIGTERM messages;
forcing our kind operators to resort to brutal process murder.

Closes-Bug: #1489209
Change-Id: I9d2886611f6db2498cd6a8f81a58f2a611f40905

subject: Make gate-rally-dsvm-neutron-neutron voting in the neutron check queue
commit_message:
Make gate-rally-dsvm-neutron-neutron voting in the neutron check queue

The decision stems from the fact that the job has been stable for some
time. Also, more scenarios are being added (e.g. [1]), and if momemtum
keeps up, it would be nice to ensure that the job stays green over
time.

Absence of the job on the gate queue is not an oversight. This is a
conscious decision the team is willing to make for the following
reasons:

a) rally runs can be expensive: every scenario may easily add 5-10
   more minutes to the whole runtime. This can have a bad compounding
   effect on the entire gate pipeline for integrated projects.
b) performance degradation may occasionally show up with the combination
   of two or more effects, the same way an intermittent failure may
   show up only after merge, however in fashion that may be less
   obvious to troubleshoot. To avoid crippling the entire gate until
   the issue is pinpointed and resolved, it is best to keep the effects
   of a potential instability confined to the neutron project only.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/392265/

Change-Id: I65c570ad0eb8aed6632dd0328b21904cc2cc008a

subject: Remove xrange for run both Python 2 and Python 3
commit_message:
Remove xrange for run both Python 2 and Python 3

In python 3, range() does what xrange() used to do and xrange() does not
exist. If you want to write code that will run on both Python 2 and
Python 3, you can't use xrange().

range() can actually be faster in some cases - eg. if iterating over the
same sequence multiple times. xrange() has to reconstruct the integer
object every time, but range() will have real integer objects.
(It will always perform worse in terms of memory however)

xrange() isn't usable in all cases where a real list is needed.
For instance, it doesn't support slices, or any list methods.

subject: Adding support for container image driver
commit_message:
Adding support for container image driver

This patch includes following:
* Glance image driver
* Docker image driver
* Added unit test cases

Whenever a request to create a container with image 'x' comes,
the request will follow as below to pull image from container
image drivers:

1. Look for image locally at location 'images_directory'.
   This is the location where all images tar downloaded from
   glance will be stored. If found, load it.
2. If not found in Step 1, look in 'image_driver_list'. This
   config is the list of image_drivers. Possible options are
   Glance and Docker now.
   Based on the priority defined in 'image_driver_list', pull
   the image from image_driver.
3. Finally create container with loaded image.

subject: Stop using nova-manage network commands
commit_message:
Stop using nova-manage network commands

The nova-manage network-related commands are deprecated,
so this replaces them with equivalent nova CLI from
python-novaclient.

Because the nova CLI calls nova-api and nova-api calls
nova-net to create the network, which calls conductor
to use the database, we have to start nova-conductor and
nova-net before we can create the network now.

This adds a new idempotent 'start_nova_process' function
which is used to start n-cond and n-net after n-api but
before creating the network and floating IP resources.
The start_nova_rest function is changed to use start_nova_process
because grenade calls start_nova which calls start_nova_rest.

In the case of full grenade, n-cond and n-net won't be running
on the new (ocata) side, so start_nova will start them.

In the case of partial grenade and non-grenade jobs, however,
n-cond and n-net will already be running when start_nova is
called.

Change-Id: I5c4291509841325e6123520131f30b64c847a17f

subject: Don't parse PCI whitelist every time neutron ports are created
commit_message:
Don't parse PCI whitelist every time neutron ports are created

The neutronv2 API is calling the method get_pci_device_devspec()
everytime a neutron port is created in order to get a PciDeviceSpec for a given
PCI device.  This method creates a new Whitelist (based on the config
CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist) and parses it every time it is called.  This
is not a huge overhead but this is obvioulsy not needed and a waste of cycles.

Since only neutronv2 API uses get_pci_device_devspec(), this commit removes
the method in favor of using the Whitelist object directly (like it is done
in the PciDevTracker).

Change-Id: Idee4e9edecff0672680f323a916201aee8eeeabd
